So, they're saying we're doing it for everybody.

turn.speaker: elizabeth_s_kertscher
turn.label: Ms. Elizabeth S. Kertscher
turn.text: --Well, Your Honor, and again prospectively I think that might very well make sense.

But when you're talking about retrospective application of this rule, by depriving these inmates of... of consideration over a period of up to 5 years, that does pose a risk to these inmates that if their circumstances change and if during that 5-year period, if somebody were to look at them and... and consider the facts of their case, that that board might very well vote to release them.
By depriving them of that consideration, then you have harmed the inmate, you have extended the time period in jail.
And that's... for that reason, even if it would be cost effective to do that, we can't go back retrospectively and implement this rule in such a way that inmates will be harmed in the process.
Going back to--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: But the policy does say that in the event of a change in circumstance, the information can be given to the board and they say they consider it.

turn.speaker: elizabeth_s_kertscher
turn.label: Ms. Elizabeth S. Kertscher
turn.text: --The policy does say that they'll consider it.

However, as we see in the case of Gary Newberry, that doesn't necessarily mean that you're going to get the consideration and that you're going to get out at the same time that you would have had the review been conducted at the... the 3-year interval.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Was that policy statement in effect at the time of the decision in this case?

turn.speaker: elizabeth_s_kertscher
turn.label: Ms. Elizabeth S. Kertscher
turn.text: Your Honor--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The decision concerning this... this inmate.

turn.speaker: elizabeth_s_kertscher
turn.label: Ms. Elizabeth S. Kertscher
turn.text: --The date of that policy is 1996.
My client's decision... my client was considered in 1994... 5.
The board tells us today that there was a previous version of this policy statement in effect.
Whether or not that's the case or what that--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Before the... you heard your opponent argue today, were you aware of the fact that there was a... the 1996 policy statement was... really repeated something that had been long in effect?

turn.speaker: elizabeth_s_kertscher
turn.label: Ms. Elizabeth S. Kertscher
turn.text: --No, Your Honor, and although counsel for petitioners said that came up at the Eleventh Circuit, that... that never was addressed at the Eleventh Circuit level.

I'm willing to... to accept counsel's representations that there was such a rule in 1995 because this policy statement and... and the ability of inmates to request this expedited consideration has been shown not to be a sufficient safeguard to really prevent these inmates from spending longer times in jail under the 8-year rule than they would under the 3-year rule.

What's also noticeably absent in this system is a safeguard that this Court relied on very heavily in the Morales case, and that was the ability of the California board, after the fact, to go back and advance the ultimate release date in the event that there had been an error or some unforeseen change in circumstances.

And it... that finding allowed this Court to find that there was basically no way an inmate in the California system was going to slip through the cracks and wind up spending more time in jail as a result.
We don't have anything like this here.
If the... if the inmate is considered and found appropriate... found to be an appropriate candidate for release, then the inmate is released at that time.
There's no opportunity after the fact to go back and correct for it.

And if we have an inmate like we have with Gary Newberry, who's considered 6 months later than he would have been under the 3-year rule, there's no opportunity to go back and give Mr. Newberry or anybody like that the 6 months that he's lost under this... under the application of the new rule.

In conclusion, Your Honor, the Georgia system on its face provides far too great a risk for inmates to serve an increased term of confinement under the 3... under the 8-year rule than they would under the 3-year rule.
We know that in the... the State of Georgia, regardless of the precise number of years of an average life sentence, we know that inmates are regularly released that are serving life sentences.
Last year the board tells us that they released 14.4 percent of the life sentenced inmates that they considered under this rule.

My client, who is 71 years old and has served 22 years in prison for his crimes, despite the severity of his crimes, is entitled to the consideration that the legislature provided for and entitled to a full and fair considerations of all the... all the relevant facts that might bear on a determination of whether or not he's suitable for parole.

By... by pushing his determination back for an 8-year period when he would have been entitled to review every 3 years under the old rule my client and others similarly situated to him are at a very significant, very meaningful level of risk of an increased sentence.
And for that reason, the decision of the Eleventh Circuit should be affirmed.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Ms. Kertscher.
Mr. Brasher, you have 1 minute left.

turn.speaker: christopher_s_brasher
turn.label: Mr. Christopher S. Brasher
turn.text: Your Honor, very briefly.
The protections in Morales existed only because that system created an expectation of parole.
It created a liberty interest.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Brasher, may I ask you... I wasn't clear on your argument whether you were making a distinction between a statute... say, a statutory change from 3 years to 8 years and the rule change.

turn.speaker: christopher_s_brasher
turn.label: Mr. Christopher S. Brasher
turn.text: I was not, Your Honor.
However, I think that it's important to note that contrary to counsel's argument, the board is not required to set periodic reconsiderations by the statute.
The statute merely calls on the board, if it adopts rules, to have rules regarding consideration and reconsideration.
The board could, therefore--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Do we have the text of the statute someplace?

turn.speaker: christopher_s_brasher
turn.label: Mr. Christopher S. Brasher
turn.text: --Pardon?

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Do we have the text of the statute someplace?

turn.speaker: christopher_s_brasher
turn.label: Mr. Christopher S. Brasher
turn.text: No, Your Honor, I don't believe so, but I believe that the... that the citation is Official Code of Georgia Annotated, 42-9-42 I believe.
But it's very close to that statute that is the rule that... the law that gives the board the ability to adopt these and promulgate these rules.
It doesn't require periodic reconsideration as has been argued by respondents.
Finally, as to Mr. Newberry's case, Mr. Newberry's case was well publicized in the news media.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Brasher.
The case is submitted.
